DOC.HEAD: Sudan Rebels Reportedly Kill 17 of Their Leaders, Imprison Others
DOC.TEXT: The rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army recently put to death 17 of its senior officers and imprisoned 29 others, a ministerial source was quoted by the Sudan News Agency as saying Wednesday. The new report said no explanation was offered for the orders purportedly given by rebel leader John Garang. The agency quoted the source as saying the rebels imprisoned 29 officers ranging from captain to lieutenant colonel ``while at the same time demanding that the government release political detainees and observe human rights.'' The military government jailed ousted Prime Minister Sadek el-Mahdi and about 50 other senior political leaders after the military took power in a coup June 30. It says they will be tried for political and economic corruption. The ministerial source said that of the rebels' five-man military council, only Garang and William Noun remained. He identified the other three only as Karbino, Silvar Care and Arok Toun, and said all were in jail. No immediate comment came from the rebels. The Christian and animist rebel army took up arms against the Moslem majority government in the north in 1983. The rebels demand more autonomy and a greater share in the country's economic wealth.
